revised_title: A Study of Sensitized Explosions: Hydrogen-Oxygen Reaction Sensitized by Nitrogen Peroxide
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on the hydrogen-oxygen reaction sensitized by nitrogen peroxide to study the effect of pressure, temperature, and foreign gases on the induction periods and explosion limits of the reaction. They found that increasing pressure causes the separation of the upper and lower limiting concentrations of the sensitizer to increase, and that all foreign gases lengthen the induction periods and eventually quench the ignition of the explosive mixture. The results provide insights into the mechanisms of chain reactions and the role of catalysts and inhibitors in controlling ignition.
